author: afdudley
content: <@!301186049323958275> I don't know where you want to talk about the lack of global semaphore, but this is where mev-geth comes from.

author: sky.cactus
content: Wherever is fine, here if you like or elsewhere if there is a better place.  ðŸ™‚

author: afdudley
content: Yeah, I just don't see how we can have functional gossip when there is MEV, and we have MEV because two transactions in the same block can modify the same state.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, you want each state entry to be touchable by one transaction per block?

author: sky.cactus
content: e.g., one Uniswap trade between a particular pair per block

author: afdudley
content: Well, I don't want that, but that fixes the problem ðŸ˜„

author: sky.cactus
content: It is an interesting point.  My gut tells me that would have some pretty severe side effects, but maybe it can be the root of some better design.

author: sky.cactus
content: Perhaps contracts could opt-in to it?  Flag certain state entries as "once per block"?

author: afdudley
content: Another way to fix the problem is to add conditionals to transactions that say, only execute my transaction against this list of merkle leafs.

author: afdudley
content: Another way is to assert the transaction will only pay the miner if the merkle leafs have a particular value at the end of the block.

author: afdudley
content: in some semi-stateless world these sorts of transactions are maybe literally 100x more reasonable than the current model, where DoSing would be trivial.

author: afdudley
content: we have to really constrain the search that tx can trigger on the miner side.

author: afdudley
content: the easiest way to do that is to make the user provide the result of the search with the transaction.

author: sky.cactus
content: I like these ideas.  They are new to me and I need to think on them more though.
